messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 23, 2021 - June 29, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-30T21:10:24Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-06-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210630-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to minor levels during this reporting period. There were two non-Earth directed CMEs, one O-type CME and another narrow C-type CME (see details below). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the O-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-06-28T20:00Z may impact OSIRIS-REx at 2021-07-01T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20210629-AL-001). 

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was briefly elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2021-06-24 (see notifications 20210624-AL-001 and 20210624-AL-002). These significantly elevated electron flux levels were associated with a brief increase in the solar wind speed and magnetic field strength detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-06-22 caused possibly by a current sheet interaction and a small transient.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to elevated energetic electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-06-28T20:00Z     ~1181           O               131/18                38                          SOHO, STEREO A   
2021-06-28T20:00Z     ~530(POS)       C               lat=3(POS)            10                          SOHO                   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-07-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Currently, there are three numbered active regions (12835, 12836, 12837) visible in the available EUV imagery from SDO and STEREO A, as well as two unnumbered active regions. Out of these active regions, active region 12835 currently displays the greatest magnetic complexity and potential for producing flares and CMEs. It produced several C-class flares in the past three days. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A southern extension of the northern polar coronal hole crossing the center of the Earth-facing disk on 2021-06-27 seems to have become geoeffective on 2021-06-30. A small equatorial coronal hole near the center of the disk might be expected to become geoeffective by 2021-07-05.

also 
## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (OSIRIS-REx)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-29T18:21:07Z
## Message ID: 20210629-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

O-type CME detected by STEREO A/SOHO.

Start time of the event: 2021-06-28T20:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~1181 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 38 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 131/18 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-06-28T20:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow). The flank of the CME will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2021-07-01T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2021-06-28T13:25:00-CME-001, 2021-06-28T20:00:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210628_202200_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210628_202200_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210628_202200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210628_202200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Osiris_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

The simulation results linked above also include an S-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery starting at 2021-06-28T13:25Z. This S-type CME is not predicted to have any notable impacts.

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-24T16:28:32Z
## Message ID: 20210624-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-06-24T15:00Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels could be related to a previous Radiation Belt Enhancement that were caused by a high speed stream detected at L1 by DSCOVR/ACE on 2021-06-15 (see notifications 20210617-AL-001, 20210617-AL-002, 20210619-AL-001, 20210621-AL-001). The enhanced electron flux levels could also be related to a increases in solar wind  speed and magnetic field strengths detected at L1 between 2021-06-22T04:00Z to 2021-06-22T12:00Z and/or a diffuse coronal hole high speed stream structure that can be seen more clearly near the central Earth-facing disk around 2021-06-20; event is still undergoing analysis.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-06-24T15:00:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 16, 2021 - June 22, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-23T19:57:24Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-06-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210623-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-06-16T00:00Z-03:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-06-15 (see notification 20210615-AL-001). Solar wind speeds from this event reached values around 620 km/s on 2021-06-15 and decreased to around 350 km/s by the end of the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES exceeded the threshold level of 1000 pfu on 2021-06-17 and remained above threshold for most of the reporting period (see notifications 20210617-AL-001, 20210617-AL-002, 20210619-AL-001, and 20210621-AL-001).  This elevated energetic electron flux was due to the high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-06-15.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate due to radiation belt enhancement following the 2021-06-15 high speed stream.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed        
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-06-29T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active Region 12833 should rotate off of the Earth-facing disk near the beginning of the outlook period; it has decreased in activity over the reporting period and is not expected to generate significant solar activity during the outlook period.  However, Active Region 12833 is expected to remain magnetically connected to Earth during the early part of the outlook period.  An unnumbered active region rotated onto the Earth-facing disk at the end of the reporting period, and is expected to generate sporadic B-class flaring throughout the outlook period, with a small likelihood of C-class flaring.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period.  A small patchy equatorial coronal hole near the Earth-facing meridian at the end of the reporting period may possibly generate some minor geomagnetic storming late in the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-21T12:13:54Z
## Message ID: 20210621-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-06-21T08:40Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-06-17T07:50Z are caused by a high speed stream starting on 2021-06-15, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 620 km/s (see notifications 20210617-AL-001, 20210617-AL-002, and 20210619-AL-001). The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 350 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-06-17T07:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-06-17T07:50Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream which arrived on 2021-06-15, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 620 km/s. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 530 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-06-17T07:50:00-RBE-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 09, 2021 - June 15, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-16T19:34:23Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-06-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210616-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period. There was 1 O-type CME and 3 C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the O-type CME initially observed in STEREO A COR2 at 2021-06-10T18:23Z and the C-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-06-10T18:36Z may have impacted Mars at 2021-06-15T13:59Z and Solar Orbiter at 2021-06-13T05:25Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20210611-AL-001). 

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-06-15T18:00Z-21:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-06-15 (see notification 20210615-AL-001). Solar wind speeds from this event reached values around 620 km/s on 2021-06-15 and remained near 600 km/s for the rest of the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-06-09T12:24Z     ~544            C               105/6                 31                          SOHO, STEREO A
2021-06-10T09:36Z     ~559            C               116/11                27                          SOHO
2021-06-10T18:23Z     ~1002           O              -122/12                34                          STEREO A, SOHO
2021-06-10T18:36Z     ~725            C              -128/-15               29                          SOHO, STEREO A                              
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-16T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-06-22T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active Region 12832 should rotate off the Earth-facing disk near the beginning of the outlook period. Active Region 12833 ended the reporting period near N25E40, and it is possible that it may generate some B-class and possibly C-class flaring throughout the outlook period. Two unnumbered active regions observed near S20E10 and S25W15 as seen on the SDO imagery at the end of the reporting period may possibly generate some activity during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period.  The arrival at L1 on 2021-06-15 of the high speed stream from a northern extension of the south polar coronal hole near S15W40 at the end of the reporting period may possibly generate some minor geomagnetic disturbance followed by a possible radiation belt enhancement early in the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES is currently elevated above background levels between 500 and 800 pfu, but has not yet crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-15T12:49:27Z
## Message ID: 20210615-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 starting at 2021-06-15T00:26Z. 

The shock is associated with the arrival of a high speed stream on 2021-06-15.

Activity ID: 2021-06-15T00:26:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Mars, Solar Orbiter)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-11T15:52:28Z
## Message ID: 20210611-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-06-10T18:23Z.

Estimated speed: ~1002 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 34 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -122/12 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-06-10T18:23:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-06-10T18:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~725 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -128/-15 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-06-10T18:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Mars and Solar Orbiter.  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach Mars at 2021-06-15T13:59Z and Solar Orbiter at 2021-06-13T05:25Z (plus minus 7 hours). 


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: 2021-06-10T18:23:00-CME-001 and 2021-06-10T18:36:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210610_215800_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210610_215800_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210610_215800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210610_215800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Mars_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210610_215800_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_SolO_timeline.gif


## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 02, 2021 - June 08, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-06-09T21:28:59Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-02T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-06-08T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210609-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-06-07T21:00Z-24:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-06-07 (see notification 20210607-AL-001). Solar wind speeds reached values around 550 km/s on 2021-06-08 and decreased to around 400 km/s by the end of the reporting period. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-06-02T20:48Z     ~572            C               157/2                 19                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2021-06-02T21:12Z     ~649            C               -47/-19               28                          SOHO                              
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-09T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-06-15T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. One or more unnumbered active regions are currently visible in STEREO A EUV imagery and are beginning to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk. These regions show potential for flaring activity during the outlook period. Active Region 2831, which recently rotated off of the Earth-facing disk, continues to produce flares on 2021-06-09 and has produced a CME first visible in SOHO C2 coronagraph at 2021-06-09T12:24Z. Analysis of this CME is still ongoing. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A northern extension of the south polar coronal hole currently visible towards the SE limb of the Earth-facing disk (as seen in the available SDO EUV imagery on 2021-06-09) may become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 26, 2021 - June 01, 2021

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There was one C-type CME (see details below).  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe and STEREO B. The leading edge of the CME was estimated to reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-05-30T15:00Z and STEREO B at 2021-05-31T18:46Z (plus minus 7 hours). The simulation also indicated that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-06-01T06:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).  The roughly estimated range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor) (see notification 20210529-AL-003). The arrival of this CME may have been detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2021-06-02T12:20Z. Analysis of this event is still ongoing. 

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period 2021-05-26T18:00Z-21:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was associated with the combined arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-05-26 and 2021-05-27 of several CMEs that started on 2021-05-22 and 2021-05-23, respectively (see notification 20210526-AL-001).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was above the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period due to the continuing effects of the high speed stream starting on 2021-05-20 (see notifications 20210522-AL-001, 20210522-AL-002, 20210524-AL-001, and 20210526-AL-002). The fluxes went back to nominal levels on 2021-05-27.  

Solar energetic particle event was detected by GOES. The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2021-05-29T03:00Z (see notifications 20210529-AL-001 and 20210529-AL-002). This solar energetic particle event was due to a long duration C9.4 flare from Active Region 12824 that peaked on 2021-05-28T22:19Z and the associated C-type CME described below (see notification 20210529-AL-003).  The energetic proton flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A also became slightly elevated, but remained below the threshold of 0.1 pfu/MeV. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the combined CME arrivals at L1 detected by DSCOVR and ACE and the solar energetic particle event mentioned above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-06-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-06-08T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Active Regions 12826, 12827, 12828, and 12829 were numbered during the previous outlook period. Active Regions 12827, 12828, and 12829 have produced multiple B-class flares and this activity is expected to continue during the outlook period as they continue to cross the Earth-facing disk.  An unnumbered Active Region currently rotating onto the STEREO A facing disk may cross onto the Earth-facing disk by the end of the outlook period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period due to the possible arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-06-02 of the CME that started on 2021-05-28 mentioned above. Two small coronal hole structures are visible on the Earth and STEREO A facing disks.  The first is centered near N05W30 and may become geoeffective in the early portion of the outlook period. The second coronal hole is centered near S20E30 and may impact STEREO A towards the first half of the reporting period.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
